titlestmt.titleproper: Guide to the Margaret Hodges Papers, 1911-2006 SC.1990.03
titlestmt.author: Katharine Pigliacelli in 2016.

profiledesc.creation: This finding aid was produced using ArchivesSpace on 2023-12-12 14:21:06 -0500.
profiledesc.langusage: Description is written in: English, Latin script.

did.abstract: The Margaret Hodges Papers document her career as storyteller, librarian, author, teacher, and advocate for childhood studies. The collection includes drafts, correspondence, teaching materials, storytelling scripts, photographs, and media.

prefercite.head: Preferred Citation
prefercite.p: Margaret Hodges Papers, 1911-2006, SC.1990.03, Archives & Special Collections, University of Pittsburgh Library System

acqinfo.head: Acquisition Information
acqinfo.p: Multiple donations made by Hodges over the course of many years while teaching at the University of Pittsburgh Library School.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Content Notes
scopecontent.p: The collection consists of 45 manuscript boxes and one oversize box and includes correspondence, interviews, research for and drafts of books, teaching materials, photographs, media, and other materials that document Margaret Hodges' work as an author and scholar of children's literature.

bioghist.head: Biography/History
bioghist.p: Sarah Margaret Hodges was born in Indianapolis, Indiana, in 1911. Her mother, Anna Marie Moore, died six months after Margaret was born. An older cousin cared for the household which included Margaret, her brother, father and grandfather. Both her father and the Second Presbyterian Church Sunday School were instrumental in introducing to her the art of storytelling.

During her sophomore year at Tudor Hall, a prep school for girls, Hodges was introduced to Fletcher Hodges, who she would marry in 1932. She attended Vassar College where she studied English and theatre and graduated with honors in 1932. In 1937, Margaret and Fletcher moved to Pittsburgh and he became curator at the Stephen Foster Memorial.

After raising three children, Hodges volunteered at the Carnegie Library of Pittsburgh. During this time she also wrote scripts for a radio program called "The Children's Bookshelf" and in 1953, she was asked to take a paid position as a storyteller for a radio program called "Let's Tell a Story." In 1964, the program became "Tell Me a Story", a nationally broadcast television program on Pittsburgh's WQED-TV.

During this time, Hodges applied for a scholarship that would enable her to earn a Master's degree in Library Science at the Carnegie Institute of Technology, now Carnegie Mellon University. Two years later, in 1958, her first book, One Little Drum, was published by Follett Publishing Company.

Hodges continued to work at the Carnegie Library until 1964, when she left to join the Head Start program as Story Specialist for Pittsburgh Public Schools. At the same time, Dr. Harold Lancour, the Dean of the University of Pittsburgh Graduate School of Library and Information Science, asked Hodges to teach a course in storytelling which lead to her eventually teaching all courses in children's services. In 1978, she retired as professor emeritus from the University of Pittsburgh.

One of Hodge's greatest contribtions was the development of Elizabeth Nesbitt Children's Book Collection. While attending the Carnegie Institute, Hodges studied under storyteller and teacher, Elizabeth Nesbitt, an experence that influenced Hodges for the rest of her life. She was able to pay tribute to her influential teacher when in 1976 she began developing the Elizabeth Nesbitt Room at the University of Pittsburgh library school. The Nesbitt Children's Book Collection, now housed at the University of Pittsburgh Archives and Special Collections, features a range of materials including chapbooks, toy books, boardbooks, and juvenile periodicals. She continued to curate and support this collection until her death in December of 2005.
During her career, Hodges also wrote and illustrated more than 60 books, including Caldecott winner St. George and the Dragon.

custodhist.head: Custodial History
custodhist.p: This collection was donated to and housed at the Elizabeth Nesbitt Room at the University of Pittsburgh School of Information Science Library until its closure in 2012, when the materials were transferred to Special Collections.

processinfo.head: Processing Information
processinfo.p: This collection was originally processed by the Elizabeth Nesbitt Room at the University of Pittsburgh School of Information Science Library. When the Information Sciences Library and Elizabeth Nesbitt Room closed in 2012, the materials were transferred to Special Collections.

Throughout 2015 and 2016, two student employees, Lauren Galloway and Katharine Pigliacelli, rehoused the collection in acid free folders and created a finding aid under the supervision of archivist, Jennifer Needham. Edits were made to folder titles to better reflect the contents and in some cases, additional series and subseries were created. The original container listing created by the Nesbitt Room is held in the case file is available upon request.

relatedmaterial.head: Related Material
relatedmaterial.p: Margaret Hodges also made manuscript donations to the following repositories: University of Oregon; University of Minnesota, Kerlan Collection; and the University of Southern Mississippi, DeGrummond Collection.

arrangement.head: Arrangement
arrangement.p: The papers are organized according to the following series:
Series II: Radio and TV Storytelling
Series III: University of Pittsburgh Graduate School of Library and Information Sciences (GSLIS)

odd.head: Previous Citation
odd.p: Maragaret Hodges Collection, 1911-2006, SC.1990.03, University of Pittsburgh Special Collections Department, University of Pittsburgh

scopecontent.head: Scope and Content Notes
scopecontent.p: Personal materials related to Hodges' childhood, education, professional life, and her many awards and honors, including the founding of the Elizabeth Nesbitt room. Papers from close friends and family are included in this series as well.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Content Notes
scopecontent.p: Hodges voluntarily wrote scripts for the radio program, "The Children's Bookshelf," until 1953 when she was asked by the Carnegie Library of Pittsburgh to take a paid position as a storyteller for a radio program called "Let's Tell a Story." Later, in 1964, the radio program became "Tell Me a Story", a nationally broadcast television program on Pittsburgh's WQED-TV.
Each subseries contains radio scripts, program guides, and related materials.
An outline of episodes for Let's Tell A Story was created by one of the student processors, Katharine Pigliacelli, and is available upon request.

University of Pittsburgh, Graduate School of Library and Information Sciences (GSLIS)

scopecontent.head: Scope and Content Notes
scopecontent.p: In 1964, the Dean of the University of Pittsburgh Graduate School of Library and Information Science, asked Mrs. Hodges to teach a course in storytelling, which eventually led to her teaching all of the courses in children's services. She retired as a professor emerita in 1978.
This series contains materials related to her various courses including syllabi, assigments, and teaching resources.

scopecontent.p: Articles written by Hodges herself or in collaboration with others in the field of children's literature. Included are multiple drafts of articles in the series, including handwritten notes and corrections. Unpublished articles can also be found.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Content Notes
scopecontent.p: Writings by Hodges that do not fit easily into any other category. Included are short stories adapted from other sources, a draft of what appears to be her only attempt at an adult fiction story, poetry, personal essays, a local newsletter that she contributed to, classwork for her graduate classes, and research and ideas for works she never wrote.

did.unittitle: The Army of the Dead, Typescript
Are You a Successful Hostess?, Typescript

scopecontent.head: Scope and Content Notes
scopecontent.p: Various media, including video (U-matic, VHS, DVD), grooved discs, audio cassettes, and 35mm slides that document Hodge's storytelling career, research, and teaching.

did.unittitle: Let's Tell A Story Grooved Discs

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Recordings of Let's Tell a Story, a regionally broadcast show on Pittsburgh's WCAE radio station. The grooved discs are housed in 20 boxes that contain 15 aluminum cored discs each for a total of 300 discs arranged according to broadcast date. Each labelled double-sided disc contains one to three programs with one to three stories per program drawn from folk and fairy tales.

did.unittitle: Tell Me A Story Video Recordings

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Materials pertaining toTell Me A Story, a nationally broadcast television program on Pittsburgh's WQED-TV that aired from the mid-1960's to 1976. Items are housed in nine boxes that include the original U-matic recordings. The collection also contains reformatted versions on VHS, DVD and Digital files. Each item contains two to four episodes of the program. Please contact Ask an Archivist to request access to view digitized episodes. Please include details of the specific episode/s that are of interest.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Content Notes
scopecontent.p: Galleys, page proofs, and illustrations for Hodges' works. Note that this series does not include original illustrations, but rather scans and photocopies of originals.
